PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 May, on motion by Mr Jull:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take this opportunity to congratulate you on your elevation. It is fair to say that you are widely respected in the House for your tolerance. On behalf of the opposition, I wish you the best. It is obviously a very difficult job and it is often most unrewarding on your own side of parliament when under some pressure.

SPEECH.PARA: The Ministers of State Amendment Bill is largely uncontroversial, stemming from section 66 of the constitution, which has a requirement that there be amendments in regard to increases in ministerial salary. This, of course, interrelates with the 1990 Remuneration and Allowances Act and with increases that stem from the relationship between the wages of parliamentarians and those of the Senior Executive Service bands.

One point that has emerged in the last week—and the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull) has given assurances that a seeming problem is being covered—relates to the impact of this move upon former ministers and the pensions of such people or their widows. Obviously, if you decrease the wages of the outer ministry, the interrelationship with former ministers' pensions or superannuation could be affected.

The context in which this bill is being presented is one of the new frugality and lean administration of the government. Great play is being made of the reduction in the size of the ministry and the decision to pay a number of the more junior ministers less money. There is reference to the disappearance of the National Media Liaison Service and the supposed disappearance of consultants. Of course, this is a new nirvana, a new Camelot in Australian politics after 13 years in the desert, and all is going to change.

On historical precedent, one has to have some doubts about this long‐term turn of events, if we have reference to the Fraser government and its early statements about what it was going to do and to a bit of the history afterwards, which involved the suppression of material in relation to areas such as wages and staffing levels. More interestingly, I heard a lot of this when, after 15 years in the wilderness, we had a new government in New South Wales and there were going to be similar changes.

The minister has a job ahead of him in curbing the kind of problem that we saw emanate from that government when similar promises were made. Interestingly, the speech of the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) made reference to his maiden speech, but he certainly skipped over the regime that operated in that state. During that period we saw very few ministers survive the actual government—whether it was the Deputy Premier who was found by ICAC to have created a `climate conducive to corruption' or the Minister for Education who resigned after tax evasion or the assistant secretary who was in a similar category or the Minister for Administrative Services who resigned after revelations of an attempt to influence the Minister for Planning. That was the kind of new broom that went through.

We have really got to have some doubts about the long‐term cost cutting and reduction in services of the ministerial wing. I can assure you that the opposition will be vigilant in these matters. It is interesting that already we are seeing the decision by five ministers to operate in their home states, supposedly for a variety of reasons. The Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) was not too interested in the comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who said that, along with the privilege of serving as a minister or parliamentary secretary, there were some personal sacrifices in terms of the time and energy that must be devoted to official duties and some loss of privacy. The only reason Dr Wooldridge can give for moving his ministerial office to Melbourne was so that he would be, as he said on 8 April on Channel 10, `close to his family'.

The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) came up with an even more preposterous proposition for why he had to be in Brisbane. On the same TV program, he said that it was to be `closer to our indigenous communities'. That is why the minister had to move his office to Brisbane. As we have seen in the last week or so, it might have more to do with his Albert Schweitzer efforts in the health field rather than with proximity to indigenous communities throughout this country.

We are already seeing the decision to move ministerial offices to home states. That is obviously going to occasion refitting. It is also going to occasion public servants getting on planes every five minutes with pieces of paper and briefings, and obviously there will be a consequential increase in cost there. So that is one area where we are seeing difficulties.

We have also seen in the last few days the pressure that has been put on the minister for Aboriginal affairs to give up his occupation and there is the continuing question over the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson). Supposedly, there is no conflict of interest with regard to his operation of that portfolio and its interrelationship with the field in which he makes a dollar. Already—despite constant assurances from those opposite that they will reduce waste, that there will not be conflict of interest, that there will be integrity in government—there are very big questions.

They made great play of who was overseas and who got whatever travel allowances et cetera, but when they tried to run a mock anti‐terrorist operation through the Protective Service coordinating centre, which runs mock anti‐terrorist activities for the ministers, they found that none of the ministers in this new government were available to undertake the operation—they were overseas or unavailable. That is typical of what we can expect.

The reality is that this bill, as is indicated, essentially decreases the amount available for the coming year because of the reduction in the size of the ministry. That reduction in salaries pays for the increase for ministers under the previous government. There is nothing controversial in the measure but essentially we will be putting forward that there is a need to be vigilant, that there is a need to be watchful, especially given the already questionable insistence and attempt by some ministers to evade the Prime Minister's requirements with regard to ministerial conduct.

There is already evidence of some ministers having a commercial interest in fields where they have ministerial responsibility. As I said, there is a need to ensure that the promises we have been given with regard to reductions in consultancies do persist and are not simply an early enthusiasm for change which, as with the Fraser government, soon disappears.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes that are before us today are twofold: one is to tidy up the mess which was left behind by the previous government and the other sets a new course for this new government. The previous Labor administration, as we all know, was just no good with money. They increased ministerial salaries and they did not appropriate the funds that were necessary to cover the cost. These amendments today are all about that. Currently, the act limits the amount to $1.615 million but Labor spent more than that in the current year because it did not budget the funds.

This legislation increases the appropriation to tidy this matter up for the current year. The amount involved is $1.64 million, which will meet the cost of paying previous ministers in the old Labor government. They are lucky that it was not a performance based pay agreement or a few of those former ministers might be owing the Australian people a large refund at the moment. Under the previous arrangements set by the old government, $1.78 million would have been the amount required in subsequent years under this legislation.

This saving might seem small in the overall scheme of things but it is a start. I applaud the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for proposing these changes, although I believe that the changes do not reflect the expertise, experience and commitment which the ministers are bringing to their jobs.

That was certainly the way they joked about it, but I must say that that gentleman, many others in the Macgregor Lions Club and other members of my community have since come to me and conceded that they see the gesture that is contained within this bill, as announced by the Prime Minister and the minister, as indicative of the sort of leadership that they wanted and expected from this government. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This is my first speech in this chamber. This bill is a pretty straightforward proposition. The main purpose is to insert in the Excise Tariff Act 1921 the definition of `prescribed division' which is currently contained in an excise by‐law. In effect, what that definition does is determine the periods of the year for calculating excise duty on crude oil under the Excise Tariff Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill has been presented as the result of advice received by the government from the Attorney‐General's Department earlier this year. That advice suggested that the transfer of the definition from the by‐law to the act should be made for the purposes of clarity, and with retrospective effect to the date that the by‐law definition came in—which was 1 July 1983.

So the amendment which this bill effects is remedial. It will put the validity of both future and past duty collections beyond challenge. We appreciate the importance of the technical amendment to secure the revenue base and it is against that background that we will be supporting the passage of the bill.

The bill also makes a drafting amendment to the Excise Tariff Act to achieve gender neutrality. We commend this as the gender neutral drafting of Commonwealth legislation was a process that we initiated when in government. So we support the passage of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1996.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to be here in the Main Committee of the 38th Parliament and to have the opportunity to speak to this bill. The purpose of the bill is to insert into the Excise Tariff Act 1921—the principal act—the definition of `prescribed division' which is currently contained in an excise by‐law. The definition is necessary for determining the periods of the year for the purposes of calculating the excise duty on crude petroleum oil under sections 6B—`old' oil, 6C—`new' oil, and 6D—`intermediate' oil, of the principal act.

SPEECH.PARA: The people in my electorate and in other country areas of Australia only know it as petrol or diesel. And their concern is about the prices, and the variety of prices, that are experienced in country Australia, and about the differences between metropolitan areas, such as Melbourne and Sydney, compared with the prices in an area such as Bendigo, which I have the honour and privilege to represent.

Country people fully accept that there may be a few cents per litre difference in the price of fuel but they will not accept the fact that between urban and rural prices there could be differentials of 10c, 15c and sometimes up to 20c per litre in the price of petrol or diesel fuel. This is a very important issue for me, as it is, I am sure, for the member for Ballarat and a number of other members representing rural constituencies. It is a very important issue and it is one which the coalition addressed during the lead‐up to the 1996 election campaign.

BREAK.PARA: The shadow minister at that time, Peter McGauran, the federal member for Gippsland, was very active on this issue during the election campaign. He introduced a proposal to introduce fairness and transparency into country petrol prices. When the shadow minister launched that in Melbourne he said that the policy that we would be implementing in government would ensure that consumers in country areas would be able to buy petrol at fair prices. He claimed that there were distortions in the market which caused unacceptable pricing differentials between metropolitan and country markets.

Since that time, of course, the coalition has been elected to government and we are looking forward now to the government and the minister implementing this policy. As a first stage in this, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has been asked to examine prices at every stage from the refinery gate to the petrol pump to investigate any anti‐competitive or discriminatory pricing schemes so that offenders can be prosecuted. These hearings will be held throughout the length and breadth of Australia and I understand that that process has already commenced. The minister has obviously been very active. He has implemented this policy and is going to make every possible endeavour to ensure that country people have access to fuel at a reasonable price.

I think that people can understand that there would be one or two cents difference in the price per litre resulting from fuel being transported from the refinery gate to country areas. They can accept that, but they certainly cannot accept the wide variation in prices that has occurred over many years.

The Keating government failed miserably in its attempts to implement any mechanism whatsoever to address this problem. It preferred to ignore the problem. It just looked at it over 13 years. In an effort to try and get a petrol pricing policy that would achieve some form of equity and balance throughout Australia, it never came up with anything that was satisfactory to country motorists.

I can recall that when the Hon. George Gear—I think he was the Assistant Treasurer at the time and is a former member now—was asked about the difference betweeen country fuel prices and their metropolitan counterparts, he said that he dismissed completely the concerns of country people and business people in country areas. He claimed, `The issue is one that just needs to die down.'

It will not die. When you are paying up to 20c a litre more for fuel than someone 150 kilometres away in Melbourne, I can assure you that the issue does not die down in an area like Bendigo. Nor would it die down as an issue in an area like Ballarat. It is on everyone's mind; it is a major factor in everyone's budget, and car expenses are a very significant factor in the cost of living in a country area.

For many people in country areas, and certainly in my area, petrol and diesel are not only essential commodities for the rural and farming community but are also very important parts of the costing of any industry or business which operates outside the metropolitan area. The additional costs which are incurred by those businesses in rural and regional areas have to be passed on to the consumer as part of their business activities. That makes other services and other commodities in regional areas more expensive than they are in metropolitan areas.

It is a very important issue. It is one which I am delighted to see the minister has tackled early in the parliamentary year at the start of the new government, after 13 years of neglect by the former government, which was not prepared to address this question. The minister has set out to try and get some transparency and some fairness into the country pricing structure. I look forward to seeing the activities of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission as it carries out its duties throughout country Australia, having hearings and inquiring into the petroleum industry to make sure that everyone is treated fairly throughout the length and breadth of Australia.

This issue will not die down as the former Assistant Treasurer, Mr George Gear, claimed it would. It will not die down. I am pleased to see the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) come into these proceedings, because he would be aware of the huge cost of petrol in his electorate and the difference that it would make to him if there were some equity and fairness in the pricing of petrol throughout rural areas of Australia.

With those few remarks, I support the progress of this bill, which is non‐controversial. I make the point that we will be watching the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission work and report back to the government. It will ensure that prices are monitored and costs and profits in the petroleum industry—including oil company distributors and service station operators—are looked at to ensure compliance with the consumer protection and competitive conduct provisions of the Trade Practices Act. Where the ACCC identifies price discrimination or unfair prices, the government will act to maintain fair business practice within the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: What I want to talk about is deeper. As it says in Isaiah, `Where there is no vision, the people perish.' I think we have a situation in Australia wherein we have a lack of vision. I want to put a scenario to you; it relates very vaguely to fuel.
